tossups.question: An early study of this poet's longest work by L. S. Dembo is titled for this author's "Sanskrit Charge." A poem by this author recalls "the songs that gypsies dealt us at Marseille" after observing that "imponderable the dinosaur sinks slow." This poet notes that "I think of cinemas, panoramic sleights," and describes seeing an "inviolate curve...till elevators drop us from our day" in a poem that describes a seagull's wings "building high over the chained bay waters Liberty." Christopher Columbus delivers a monologue in this author's poem "Ave (AH-vay) Maria." This author aimed to provide a more optimistic counterpart to T. S. tossups.question: Circumstantial evidence for this idea includes the existence of a non-functional "handle" on acetyl-CoA and a prosthetic group on the ring of vitamin B·12. Walter Gilbert coined the name of this theory, building off Tom Cech's (sehtchz) work in Tetrahymena (TET-ruh-HIGH-men-uh). A 2020 paper by Szostak (SOSS-tack) et al. supported this theory by showing that arabinose (uh-RAB-in-ose) derivatives can increase the stability and synthesis rate of certain polymers. One paper supporting this theory encased molecules from Azoarcus (AY-zo-ARK-us) into droplets to generate autocatalytic sets. Alternatives to this idea include ones based on polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and iron-sulfur clusters. This idea is supported by the existence of self-splicing introns and ribozymes. Personal growth and unchallenged coping ability characterize a positive form of this phenomenon prefixed "eu-." Resistance to this phenomenon drops off during the exhaustion stage of a three-part syndrome studied by Hans Selye. Incongruous job demand and control are the focus of one of this phenomenon's "occupational" models. Fight or flight is termed an "acute" response to this phenomenon, which over-stimulates the body's HPA axis in a "chronic" form experienced by many workaholics. tossups.question: During this war, the population of Grand Bahama Island nearly doubled to accommodate a new function accessed by ships such as the Syren and Fingal. A so-called "famine" in Lancashire (LANK-uh-shur) caused by this conflict pushed Parliament to enact the Public Works Manufacturing Districts Act. A veteran of this conflict, John O'Neill, became a major leader of the Fenian raids, which in part emulated the St. Albans raid that occurred during this conflict. Napoleon III strategically launched the French intervention of Mexico as this other war raged. tossups.question: A free-trade agreement that George W. Bush signed with this country made its citizens the only ones eligible for an E-3 visa to the US. Businesses such as a2 Milk in this country have found a large market selling to daigou, small buyers who ship food back to China. In 2017, the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue reformed after this country left it in 2010. Google threatened to pull out of this country over a "link tax" supported by a local media tycoon. Between 2013 to 2015, this country went through four different prime ministers amidst the first-ever repeal of a carbon tax. Diane Gelon helped get this artwork exhibited at unusual locations such as the top floor of a Chicago office building and Boston's Cyclorama. This artwork was the first piece purchased for the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center at the Brooklyn Museum. Alice Walker criticized the only parts of this artwork to depict faces. This work's artist responded to Esther Allen's criticism about a lack of Latino representation by pointing to the 999 names on its Heritage Floor. Georgia O'Keefe is a "guest of honor" in this artwork and has a vulva-like plate on a triangular table. The figures of merit for some of these devices include a measure of how fast their output changes measured in volts per microsecond, as well as a measure of their ability to eliminate identical signals called their common-mode rejection ratio. The triode vacuum tube was the first practical one of these non-switching devices, which are symbolized by a triangle on a circuit diagram. tossups.question: This book, whose title subject is replaced with "Brutes" in a satire by the Neoplatonist Thomas Taylor, led Horace Walpole to call its author a "hyena" and "philosophizing serpent." The dedication of this book frames it as a response to a report in which Talleyrand suggests some should pursue a merely "domestic" form of a certain action. The gothic novel Maria is a sequel to this book that serves as a sequel to a similarly titled pamphlet responding to the Reflections on the Revolution in France. Its fifth chapter opens with an extended critique of "Sophia," the "perfect" counterpart to "Emilius" in a novelistic treatise by Rousseau. tossups.question: In Incan mythology, the spirits within these features were called apu. The Hero Twins defeat Zipacna and Cabrakan, the sons of Seven Macaw, by duping one into traveling to a non-existing one of these features and trapping the other in another of these features. The princess Iztaccíhuatl died of grief after falsely being told her lover Popocatépetl died in battle, leading them both to be transformed into two of these features. Tlaloc was said to reside in a sacred one of these features on the border of the state of Puebla. Quetzlcoatl transformed into an ant to travel to one of these features and retrieve corn for humanity to grow. tossups.question: Using hyperbolic interpolation instead of linear interpolation was used to improve a model of this phenomenon by Jim Blinn. Three interactions subscripted "s," "d" and "a" feature in a model of this phenomenon named for Bui Tuong Phong (bwee twong fong). tossups.question: 400 soldiers from this colony charged the British line at the Battle of Long Island, giving George Washington time to retreat. Josias Fendall led a failed bloodless revolution in this colony. In emulation of the Boston Tea Party, patriots in this colony threw tea into the Chester River. This colony opposed its northern neighbor in Cresap's War. After Henry Darnell was appointed to lead this colony, John Coode's "Associators" overthrew him. William Stone failed to take control of this colony after losing the Battle of the Severn. William Claiborne's claim to this colony's Kent Island led to the Plundering Time. A "New" form of this ideology is promoted by Daisaku Ikeda, whose Soka Gakkai International and Taiwan's Fo Guang Shan promote Buddhist versions of this ideology that provides another name for Felix Adler's Ethical Culture movement. Paul Kurtz and Edwin Wilson declared "no deity will save us" in a 1973 manifesto for the "secular" form of this ideology, for which an "oration" preceding 900 theses by Pico della Mirandola serves as an earlier manifesto. The so-called "prince" of this ideology wrote Handbook of a Christian Knight, compiled the Textus Receptus, and penned a satirical encomium narrated by Plutus's daughter Folly. tossups.question: This law, alongside the assumption that only a single complex is formed, underpins the slope-ratio method. The airmass factor appears in an exponential term in a version of this law used for atmospheric applications. A buffer must be added to a weak acid to prevent its proportionality constant from changing and causing deviations from this law. For larger concentrations of analyte, stray radiation in instruments causes negative deviations from this law. This law relates changes observed from a detector pointed at a sample in a cuvette. tossups.question: A player of this instrument performed with the nightingales in her garden during a 1924 BBC broadcast. This was the primary instrument of John Barbirolli, who conducted a 1965 recording of a concerto for it premiered by Felix Salmond. In 2018, Paradis's Sicilienne and Schubert's "Ave Maria" were played on this instrument by Sheku Kanneh-Mason at the Royal Wedding. That essay credits Fanny Davenport with popularizing a new design for a kind of this object, which is traditionally said to have been popularized by Sarah Bernhardt in a Victorien Sardou (vik-toh-ree-en SAR-doo) play. The Treaty of Turku ended a war sometimes named for these objects that ceded additional territory on top of the Treaty of Nystad. Two parties named for these objects vied for power during Sweden's Age of Liberty. Works in this genre, one of which was parodied in the opening line "My uncle, of most honest principles" from Eugene Onegin (oh-NAY-gin), are the most enduring output of Ivan Krylov. The Supreme Court ruled that existing "conspiracy" charges did not allow this concept to protect Frank Felix. The dual sovereignty doctrine sets limits on this legal concept, which does not apply if a judge was bribed since the defendant was not at risk in the first place. bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. This argument relies on a proposition called "Leibniz's lapse" in which only weak actualization occurs. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this argument given in a 1977 book titled for "God, Freedom," and a certain concept. It responds to four supposed contradictory propositions made by J. L. Mackie.
The free-will defense responds to Mackie's claim that the existence of an omnibenevolent God is contradictory to this concept's existence. Theodicies respond to this concept's namesake "problem".

A thinker with this surname stated that evil things cannot be necessary in his essay "The Concept of Evil." A thinker with this surname, who wrote that rich people are morally obligated to donate money in his essay "Famine, Affluence, and Morality," popularized the idea of "speciesism."

parts: Name this author of the novel Jasmine. This author lived in Canada at the time of the Air India Flight 182 bombing, which inspired her story "The Management of Grief."
A phrase from The Scarlet Letter titles this author's collection Unaccustomed Earth, whose focus on Indian Americans is shared by her earlier collection Interpreter of Maladies.
Though her mother Anita last published in 2011, releasing the collection The Artist of Disappearance, this Indian-born author has not published since her acclaimed 2006 novel The Inheritance of Loss.

Dimitrios Ioannidis (yoh-NAI-dis) took control of the Greek junta after a controversial 1973 referendum regarding this former king. Pre-junta politics deteriorated during the Apostasia Incident, in which this man repeatedly failed to nominate a Center Union minister.

parts: Name this type of design feature, which includes the Persian-inspired charbagh (CHAR-buh). Four water channels divide 32 of these features surrounding Humayun's tomb meant to evoke Jannah.

William Mustoe worked alongside this architect who designed New Delhi with Herbert Baker. A new parliament building is the highlight of an ongoing project to renovate the Central Vista designed by Herbert Baker and this architect.

Scheduled for completion in October 2022, India's new parliament building will theme its lower and upper houses around peacocks and this national flower, respectively. Delhi's popular Baháʼí temple is built to resemble this flower.

bonuses.leadin: Tall buildings can oscillate substantially in the plane of the wind due to the "shedding" of these phenomena, whose frequency is quantified by the Strouhal number. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these phenomena. They lend their name to a quantity equal to the curl of velocity, which is denoted by lowercase "omega."
Vortex shedding can become irregular as part of this high-Reynolds number fluid phenomenon, which can cause plane passengers to suffer bumpy rides.

As fluid separates around a bluff body, vortex shedding often forms this characteristic pattern sometimes named for a Hungarian-American scientist. This lengthy repeated pattern of vortices sometimes causes suspended telephone lines to "sing."

bonuses.leadin: Cairo is known as the "city of a thousand" of these architectural features. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these towers that are built atop mosques from where the muezzin delivers the call to prayer.

The Minaret of al-Ghuri and the Minaret of Qaytbay ("KITE-bye") adorn this first mosque established in Cairo. It later evolved into the second-oldest degree-granting institution in the world and is broadly considered the most prestigious university in Sunni Islam.

The minarets of the largest mosque in Cairo, Ibn Tulun, were based on a 52-meter tall minaret with a spiral ramp as part of the Great Mosque of this Iraqi city. This city north of Baghdad on the Tigris was briefly the capital of the Abbasid Caliphate.

bonuses.leadin: These astronomical events were first observed by the Vela (VAY-la) satellites, which were originally intended to look for covert nuclear tests. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these most electromagnetically intense events to have occurred since the Big Bang. Though their sources are ill-understood, it is known that they can be produced by hypernovas.

Robert Duncan and Christopher Thompson first proposed the existence of these astronomical objects to explain a 1979 gamma ray burst. These objects are widely accepted to be the identity of soft gamma repeaters.
Magnetars are a highly-magnetized type of these stars, whose mergers can cause short gamma-ray bursts. These incredibly dense stars are made up of a certain subatomic particle.
answers: magnetars [prompt on pulsars; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, neutron stars]
formatted_answers: magnetars [prompt on pulsars; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, neutron stars]

bonuses.leadin: George James's book Stolen Legacy claims that Democritus drew inspiration for atomic theory from the name of a deity from this continent. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this continent, which Mary Lefkowitz argues did not spawn Greek civilization in a book titled Not Out of this continent. The first human is thought to have been born on this continent.

James stated that Egyptians first developed the idea of metempsychosis (MET-em-sai-KOH-sis), which was adapted in the philosophical teachings of this man from Samos whose disciples believed that all existence is defined by ten pairs of opposing qualities.
Lefkowitz's Not Out of Africa was written in response to this Martin Bernal book, which argues that Greek civilization developed directly from Egyptian and Phoenician influences.
answers: Black Athena: The Afroasiatic Roots of Classical Civilization
formatted_answers: Black Athena: The Afroasiatic Roots of Classical Civilization

bonuses.leadin: Vidushaka fakes being bitten by a serpent in order to procure one of these objects from Queen Dharini in the play Mālavikā and Agnimitra. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects. In The Recognition of Shakuntala, Dushyanta does not recognize his lover after Shakuntala drops one of these objects into a river.
The Recognition of Shakuntala is by Kalidasa, who wrote in this language. This language was also used to write the Mahabharata. (mah-ha-BAH-ruh-tuh)
This character is swallowed up by the earth at the end of Kalidasa's poem Raghuvamsa. Prithvi declares this character to be chaste at the end of a play by Bhavabhuti.

bonuses.leadin: Born from a thunder god's footprint, this goddess and her husband gifted humanity with innovations such as music and marriage as the first of the Three Sovereigns. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this snake-bodied mother goddess, the spouse of Fuxi. This goddess is credited with creating humanity, first by molding clay with her hands, then by swinging a rope with her husband.

Nüwa's husband Fuxi invented fishing nets for humanity as a loophole for a rule made by this deity. Among this deity's nine sons is the turtle-shelled Bixi, who is often included at the base of steles since he likes to carry heavy loads.

Fuxi invented calligraphy for humanity after sighting this text on the side of a dragon horse. King Wen developed hexagrams for interpreting this divination text, in contrast to Fuxi's binary sequence.
answers: I Ching [or Yi Jing; accept Book of Changes or Classic of Changes]
formatted_answers: I Ching [or Yi Jing; accept Book of Changes or Classic of Changes]

bonuses.leadin: Several men in drag were among arrested in 1901 at the Dance of the 41 in Tabacalera (tah-bah-kah-LAIR-ah) during the administration of this president, who, despite announcing a "no re-election" policy, was re-elected six times. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this president, who was advised by a group named for governing according to "scientific" principles.
Francisco Madero called for an armed rebellion after Porfirio Díaz was named president of this country for the sixth time in a fraudulent 1910 election.

Many people believed that Díaz would not run for re-election in 1910 following the publication of this journalist's interview in Pearson's Magazine in 1908. Earlier, this journalist controversially reported on the Port Arthur massacre for Joseph Pulitzer's New York World newspaper.
answers: Porfirio Díaz [José de la Cruz Porfirio Díaz Mori] [the advisors were the científicos]
formatted_answers: Porfirio Díaz [José de la Cruz Porfirio Díaz Mori] [the advisors were the científicos]

bonuses.leadin: Stuart Hameroff proposed that consciousness arises from quantum processes in these cellular structures. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these structures. Dyneins ("DINE-ins") "walk" towards the minus end of these structures, while kinesins "walk" towards their plus end.
Specific arrangements of microtubules appear both in cilia and these structures, whose whip-like motion helps propel sperm cells.

The bacterial protein flagellin is recognized by the fifth of this family of receptors in mammals, whose seventh member is activated by imiquimod. Most of these receptors activate a Myd88-dependent pathway.

bonuses.leadin: While in a cave with the kidnapped woman Charite (CHA-rih-tay), this character hears the story of Cupid and Psyche. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this protagonist of the Roman novel The Golden Ass, whose name is shared with the novel's author.
Lucius first becomes intrigued by magic after hearing a story from this character, who comically fails to hang himself after replacing his friend Socrates's heart with a sponge.

Lucius's transformation into a donkey gives the novel its common title Metamorphoses, but it should not be confused with the long poem Metamorphoses by this Roman poet, who was exiled to Tomis and wrote Ars Amatoria.

bonuses.leadin: Evgeny Kissin's Four Piano Pieces closes with a jazzy piece in this form shared by the jazz-inspired third piece in Nikolai Kapustin's Eight Concert Etudes. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this form of Prokofiev's D minor Opus 11, which opens with a repeated D traded between the left and right hands.

A toccata that New York Times reviewer Allan Kozinn called "An explosive burst of rock n' roll with a chromatic edge" closes Prokofiev's middle "War" sonata, which bears this number. It's also the number of Shostakovich's "Leningrad," which is the middle of his symphonic output if you round down.

While studying under Myaskovksy (mee-AZ-KOHV-skee), this composer wrote an E-flat minor toccata popularized by classmate Lev Oborin. In that toccata and the ballet Gayane, he borrowed from the music of his native Armenia.

bonuses.leadin: The Box-Jenkins method uses ARMA or ARIMA models, which both have a moving average and this property, for economic forecasting. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property of econometric models which output the variable of interest as a function of its lagged values.
Autoregression is often used to model "series" of data indexed in order of this variable. This variable can be measured in months, quarters, or years.
An ARMA model may be selected to fit a time series' data by a set of criteria named for Hirotogu Akaike and this concept. In contract theory, this concept can be transmitted via signaling.
answers: autoregresssion [or autoregressive models; or autoregressive moving average models or autoregressive integrated moving average models; prompt on autocorrelation by asking “what property of the model accounts for autocorrelation in the data?”]
formatted_answers: autoregresssion [or autoregressive models; or autoregressive moving average models or autoregressive integrated moving average models; prompt on autocorrelation by asking “what property of the model accounts for autocorrelation in the data?”]

bonuses.leadin: A section of W. G. Sebald's novel The Rings of Saturn discusses this author's meeting with Roger Casement in Matadi. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author. The frame story of a book by this author involves a man suddenly declaring that "this also...has been one of the dark places of the earth" while on the Nellie.
Conrad's time on the Congo River inspired this novella, in which Charles Marlow chooses to withhold the fact that Kurtz's last words were, "The horror! The horror!"

Conrad reused the name of the real-life Congo steamer official Alphonse Keyaerts in this story, in which Keyarts and Carlier both end up dead after fighting over sugar while trading slaves and ivory deep in the jungle.

bonuses.leadin: The Kepert model modifies this theory to account for the structure of coordination complexes. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this theory that predicts the molecular geometry of molecules based on the number of electron pairs surrounding the central atom. It has a five-letter acronym.

A molecule's geometry can also be described by these constructs, which predicts the symmetry of molecules. These constructs classify molecules by the existence of a Cn axis, a reflection plane, an inversion center, and improper rotations.
This molecular geometry is represented in AXE notation as AX7E0. The Bartell mechanism of pseudorotation only occurs in molecules with this geometry.
answers: VSEPR theory [or valence shell electron pair repulsion theory]
formatted_answers: VSEPR theory [or valence shell electron pair repulsion theory]

bonuses.leadin: In his essay "Radical Reversibility," Yve-Alain Bois divided this artist's works into three discontinuous stages, the second of which included prints of meaningless shapes in space called "prouns." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Russian Jewish artist, a member of the UNOVIS group who created a visual book for the song Had Gadya.

"Radical Reversibility" identifies the earliest period of Lissitzky's work as inspired by this artist. The UNOVIS group was founded in Vitebsk by Kazimir Malevich and this artist of I and the Village.

Bois stated that Lissitzky's second phase, including works such as Beat the Whites with the Red Wedge, belonged to this movement. Malevich's "White on White" marked a monochrome shift in this Russian geometrical movement.

bonuses.leadin: Chaitanya Mahaprabhu reversed the order of the names presented in the Kali-Santarana Upanishad's version of this "Mahamantra" when he spread it through India around 1500 AD. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the common two-word name of this Vaishnavite mantra that serves as the colloquial name for Swami Prabhupada's Gaudiya-descended ISKCON movement. It is alternated with "hallelujah" in George Harrison's song "My Sweet Lord."
In the upanayana (oo-puh-NAY-uh-nuh) ceremony, initiates receive a sacred thread and learn this Rig Vedic mantra named for its octosyllabic meter, which praises the solar deity Savitr.

Chanting mantras can be done as part of this kind of yoga named for the Sanskrit for "love" or "devotion." Raja is sometimes added to a classification from the Gita that contrasts it with karma and jnana yoga.

bonuses.leadin: Harvey O'Connor wrote a scathing biography of this man titled for his Millions. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man whom Wright Patman attempted to have impeached. This Secretary of the Treasury's policies were largely blamed for worsening the Great Depression.

O'Connor's biography, Mellon's Millions, states that Mellon founded Union Steel Company with Henry Clay Frick as a potential competitor to this man's namesake steel company. With Mellon, this industrialist names a technology-focused university in Pittsburgh.

O'Connor's negative biography of Mellon exemplified his trend of supporting the middle-class, which led him to be arrested for supporting a general strike in this city. Norm Stamper resigned after using pepper spray to suppress 1999 anti-globalization protests in this city.

bonuses.leadin: This woman was expelled from the Unity Party for not supporting her vice-president, Joseph Boakai (bwah-KYE), in a 2017 election. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this politician who lost to Charles Taylor in 1997 but defeated George Weah (WEE-uh) in 2005 to become the first elected female head of state in Africa.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf was president of this African country, which was founded by formerly enslaved people from the United States.

Sirleaf shared the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize with Tawakkol Karman (TAH-wah-kool KAR-mahn) and this Liberian activist, who was a founding member of the Women in Peacebuilding Network. This woman helped end Liberia's civil war in 2003 by threatening to disrobe.
